questions.question: A civil engineer tests how the span length of a bridge affects the maximum load it can support before bending. In this experiment, what is the 'maximum load' called?
questions.explanation: The dependent variable is the factor that is measured or observed in response to changes in the independent variable. Here, the maximum load is measured in response to changes in span length.

questions.question: A scientist writes: 'If the temperature of a gas is increased at constant volume, then the pressure will increase linearly.' Identify this step of the scientific method.
questions.explanation: A hypothesis is a testable prediction stated in an 'If...then...' format about the relationship between variables.

questions.question: The wavelength of a specific ultraviolet light ray is $0.000000345\text{ m}$. Express this in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 7 places to the right: $0.000000345 = 3.45 \times 10^{-7}\text{ m}$.

questions.question: The total number of stars in a particular galaxy is estimated at $315,000,000,000$. Express this number in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 11 places to the left: $315,000,000,000 = 3.15 \times 10^{11}$.

questions.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement $0.0050800\text{ kg}$?
questions.explanation: Leading zeros are not significant. The digits $5$, $0$, $8$, $0$, and the trailing $0$ are significant, giving a total of 5 significant figures.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a fundamental (base) quantity in physics.
questions.explanation: Thermodynamic temperature is one of the seven SI base quantities. Acceleration and density are derived quantities.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a derived quantity.
questions.explanation: Momentum is derived from mass and velocity ($p = mv$). Luminous intensity and time are fundamental quantities.

questions.question: Which of these is a fundamental SI unit?
questions.explanation: The mole (mol) is the SI base unit for amount of substance. Newton and Joule are derived units.

questions.question: Which of these is a derived SI unit?
questions.explanation: The Pascal (Pa) is a derived unit for pressure ($1\text{ Pa} = 1\text{ N/m}^2$). Kelvin and second are fundamental SI units.

questions.question: A high-speed elevator moves at a speed of $54\text{ km/h}$. Convert this speed to meters per second ($\text{m/s}$).
questions.explanation: To convert from km/h to m/s, divide by $3.6$: $54 \div 3.6 = 15\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A tropical bird flies at a speed of $22.5\text{ m/s}$. What is its speed in kilometers per hour ($\text{km/h}$)?
questions.explanation: To convert from m/s to km/h, multiply by $3.6$: $22.5 \times 3.6 = 81\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A fiber-optic core has a diameter of $0.000125\text{ m}$. How many millimeters (mm) is this diameter?
A structural cable is $48{,}200\text{ mm}$ long. Express this length in meters.
A telescope has a focal length of $145.2\text{ cm}$. What is this length in meters?
A floor mat has an area of $9{,}400\text{ cm}^2$. Convert this area to square meters ($\text{m}^2$).

A remote-controlled car travels $600\text{ m}$ due North, then immediately turns around and travels $200\text{ m}$ due South. The entire trip takes $80\text{ s}$. Calculate the car's average velocity.
questions.explanation: Displacement is $600\text{ m}$ North minus $200\text{ m}$ South, which equals $400\text{ m}$ North. Average velocity $= \text{displacement} / \text{time} = 400\text{ m} / 80\text{ s} = 5\text{ m/s}$ North.

questions.question: A skateboarder increases speed uniformly from $1\text{ m/s}$ to $21\text{ m/s}$ in $5\text{ s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the skateboarder's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Acceleration is calculated using $a = \frac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \frac{21 - 1}{5} = \frac{20}{5} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A train slows down uniformly from $40\text{ m/s}$ to $10\text{ m/s}$ in $10\text{ s}$. Calculate the acceleration of the train, including the correct sign to indicate direction.
questions.explanation: $a = \frac{10 - 40}{10} = \frac{-30}{10} = -3\text{ m/s}^2$. The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is in the direction opposite to the velocity (deceleration).

questions.question: A swimmer swims one lap in a $25\text{ m}$ pool, meaning they swim $25\text{ m}$ down and $25\text{ m}$ back to the start. The lap takes $50\text{ s}$. Calculate the swimmer's average speed and the magnitude of their average velocity.
questions.explanation: Average speed is total distance over time: $\frac{50\text{ m}}{50\text{ s}} = 1\text{ m/s}$. Average velocity is displacement over time: displacement $= 0$ (returns to start), so velocity $= 0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A hiker walks $12\text{ km}$ due South and then $5\text{ km}$ due West. Calculate the total distance traveled and the magnitude of the hiker's displacement from the starting point.
questions.explanation: Total distance is the sum of the path lengths: $12 + 5 = 17\text{ km}$. Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish, found using the Pythagorean theorem: $\sqrt{12^2 + 5^2} = \sqrt{144 + 25} = \sqrt{169} = 13\text{ km}$.

questions.question: A luggage carousel at an airport moves at a constant speed of $0.6\text{ m/s}$ in a circle. Is this an example of uniform motion?
options: Yes, because the speed is constant
Yes, because it is moving at a constant rate
No, because it is moving slowly
questions.explanation: Uniform motion requires both constant speed and constant direction (straight-line motion). Since the direction changes in a circle, it is not uniform motion, even though the speed is constant.

questions.question: On a displacement-time graph, the line is straight and sloping upward. Describe the velocity of the object.
questions.explanation: A straight line with a constant positive slope on a displacement-time graph indicates uniform positive velocity.

questions.question: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $+14\text{ m/s}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph means the velocity is constant (not changing). Therefore, the acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A person standing on a bus falls backward when the bus suddenly accelerates forward. Name the property of the person that is responsible for this.
questions.explanation: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion. The person's body tends to stay at rest while the bus accelerates forward, so they fall backward.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to accelerate a $0.8\text{ kg}$ object at $15\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's Second Law: $F = ma = 0.8\text{ kg} \times 15\text{ m/s}^2 = 12\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A climber pulls down on a rock edge with a force of $400\text{ N}$. According to Newton's Third Law, what is the magnitude of the force the rock exerts upward on the climber?
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Therefore, the rock exerts a force of $400\text{ N}$ upward on the climber.

questions.question: Calculate the weight of an $18\text{ kg}$ object on Earth, where the acceleration due to gravity $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Weight is given by $W = mg = 18\text{ kg} \times 9.8\text{ m/s}^2 = 176.4\text{ N}$.

questions.question: An object weighs $140\text{ N}$ on a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is $4\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the mass of the object?
questions.explanation: From $W = mg$, the mass is $m = \frac{W}{g} = \frac{140\text{ N}}{4\text{ m/s}^2} = 35\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $60\text{ kg}$ crate is resting on a horizontal floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the floor is $0.25$. Calculate the force of friction acting on the crate if it is sliding. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: The friction force is $f = \mu N = \mu mg = 0.25 \times 60 \times 10 = 150\text{ N}$.

questions.question: If the friction force acting on a sliding object is $90\text{ N}$ and the coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.45$, what is the mass of the object? ($g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Using $f = \mu mg$, we solve for mass: $m = \frac{f}{\mu g} = \frac{90}{0.45 \times 10} = 20\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $5\text{ kg}$ laptop is placed on top of a $15\text{ kg}$ table. A horizontal force of $100\text{ N}$ is applied to the table. Ignoring friction, find the acceleration of the table and laptop together.
questions.explanation: The total mass being accelerated is $5\text{ kg} + 15\text{ kg} = 20\text{ kg}$. Using Newton's Second Law, $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{100\text{ N}}{20\text{ kg}} = 5\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Two blocks, one with a mass of $22\text{ kg}$ and the other with a mass of $18\text{ kg}$, are tied together by a rope and pulled by a $240\text{ N}$ force across a frictionless surface. What is the acceleration of the system?
questions.explanation: The total mass is $22 + 18 = 40\text{ kg}$. The acceleration is $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{240\text{ N}}{40\text{ kg}} = 6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A heavy door is pushed at a constant speed across a floor by a force of $42\text{ N}$. What is the magnitude of the friction force acting on the door?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means the net force is zero. Therefore, the applied force must exactly balance the friction force: $f_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} = 42\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $200\text{ N}$ force pulls a $25\text{ kg}$ object across a surface. The force of friction opposing the motion is $50\text{ N}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: The net force is $F_{\text{net}} = 200\text{ N} - 50\text{ N} = 150\text{ N}$. Acceleration is $a = \frac{F_{\text{net}}}{m} = \frac{150\text{ N}}{25\text{ kg}} = 6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $180\text{ N}$ horizontal force pushes a $30\text{ kg}$ block, causing it to accelerate at $4\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the block?
questions.explanation: The net force required to produce the acceleration is $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 30 \times 4 = 120\text{ N}$. Since the applied force is $180\text{ N}$, the friction force must be $F_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} - F_{\text{net}} = 180 - 120 = 60\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A motorboat moves through the water at a constant speed, overcoming $320\text{ N}$ of water drag and $80\text{ N}$ of mechanical friction from its drive system. Find the total applied thrust needed to maintain this motion.
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero net force. Therefore, the thrust must balance the total resistance: $F_{\text{thrust}} = 320\text{ N} + 80\text{ N} = 400\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A truck's engine provides a forward force of $4{,}500\text{ N}$. The road friction is $1{,}200\text{ N}$. If the truck moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the air drag?
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force is zero. Therefore, the thrust must equal the sum of the resistive forces: $4{,}500 = 1{,}200 + F_{\text{drag}}$, so $F_{\text{drag}} = 4{,}500 - 1{,}200 = 3{,}300\text{ N}$.

questions.question: The applied force on an object is $560\text{ N}$, and the air drag acting on it is $410\text{ N}$. If the object moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the mechanical friction?
questions.explanation: For constant velocity, the net force is zero, so the sum of resistive forces must equal the applied force. Therefore, $560 = 410 + f_{\text{friction}}$, so $f_{\text{friction}} = 560 - 410 = 150\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A friction force acts on a sliding block, opposing its motion and slowing it down. Is the work done by the friction force on the block positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The friction force acts in the direction opposite to the block's displacement. Since the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by friction is negative.

questions.question: A horse pulls a carriage forward, and the carriage moves in the direction of the pulling force. Is the work done by the horse on the carriage positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The horse exerts a forward force on the carriage, and the carriage's displacement is also forward. Force and displacement are in the same direction, so the work done by the horse is positive.

questions.question: A $3.5\text{ kg}$ bowling ball is sitting on a shelf that is $12\text{ m}$ above the floor. Calculate the ball's gravitational potential energy relative to the floor. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is given by $GPE = mgh = 3.5\text{ kg} \times 10\text{ m/s}^2 \times 12\text{ m} = 420\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $0.4\text{ kg}$ ball is moving at a speed of $25\text{ m/s}$. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is calculated using $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}(0.4)(25)^2 = 0.2 \times 625 = 125\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A block has $500\text{ J}$ of gravitational potential energy at the top of a slide. At the bottom of the slide, it has $420\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy. How much energy was converted to heat due to friction?
questions.explanation: The energy lost to heat is the difference between the initial potential energy and the final kinetic energy: $500\text{ J} - 420\text{ J} = 80\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A rocket accelerates while traveling horizontally through space. Describe the change in its kinetic energy (KE).
questions.explanation: As the rocket accelerates, its speed increases. Kinetic energy is directly related to speed, so its KE is increasing.

questions.question: A skydiver is falling at a constant terminal velocity. Describe the state of their gravitational potential energy (PE).
questions.explanation: As the skydiver falls at a constant speed, their height above the ground decreases. Gravitational potential energy is directly proportional to height, so PE is decreasing.

questions.question: A car cruises at a constant speed on a level road. Describe its mechanical energy (the sum of KE and PE).
questions.explanation: Constant speed means KE is constant. Level road means height (and thus PE) is constant. Therefore, the total mechanical energy (KE + PE) is constant.

questions.question: An unstretched spring has a length of $15\text{ cm}$. When a mass is hung from it, the spring stretches to a total length of $22.4\text{ cm}$. Calculate the extension of the spring.
questions.explanation: The extension is the increase in length: $\text{extension} = \text{final length} - \text{original length} = 22.4\text{ cm} - 15\text{ cm} = 7.4\text{ cm}$.

questions.question: An electric motor uses $5{,}000\text{ J}$ of electrical energy to perform $4{,}250\text{ J}$ of useful work. Calculate the efficiency of the motor.
questions.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of useful work output to energy input, expressed as a percentage: $\left(\frac{4{,}250}{5{,}000}\right) \times 100\% = 85\%$.

questions.question: Calculate the total resistance of three resistors with resistances $15\,\Omega$, $45\,\Omega$, and $90\,\Omega$ when they are connected in series.
questions.explanation: For resistors in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances: $R_{\text{total}} = 15 + 45 + 90 = 150\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the total equivalent resistance of three identical $120\,\Omega$ resistors when they are connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = \frac{R}{n} = \frac{120\,\Omega}{3} = 40\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $10\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in series. This combination is then connected in parallel with a single $20\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The series pair has a resistance of $10 + 10 = 20\,\Omega$. This $20\,\Omega$ resistor is in parallel with the other $20\,\Omega$ resistor. The equivalent resistance is given by $\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{20} + \frac{1}{20} = \frac{2}{20} = \frac{1}{10} \rightarrow R = 10\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $60\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is then connected in series with a $20\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel pair has an equivalent resistance of $\frac{60}{2} = 30\,\Omega$. Adding this in series with the $20\,\Omega$ resistor gives a total of $30 + 20 = 50\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the electrostatic force between two point charges of $2\,\mu\text{C}$ and $8\,\mu\text{C}$ separated by a distance of $0.04\text{ m}$ in a vacuum. (Use $k = 9 \times 10^9\text{ NÂ·m}^2/\text{C}^2$).
If the distance between two point charges is tripled ($3r$), while the charges themselves remain unchanged, how does the magnitude of the electrostatic force between them change?
options: It becomes $1/3$ of the original force ($F/3$)
It becomes $1/9$ of the original force ($F/9$)
It becomes $1/27$ of the original force ($F/27$)
questions.explanation: Coulomb's Law states that force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance: $F \propto \frac{1}{r^2}$. Tripling the distance ($r \rightarrow 3r$) reduces the force by a factor of $3^2 = 9$, so the new force is $F/9$.

questions.question: Three identical positive point charges are placed in a straight line with equal spacing between them. What is the direction of the net electrostatic force on the charge located in the middle?
options: Zero (the forces from the two outer charges cancel out)
questions.explanation: The left charge repels the middle charge to the right. The right charge repels the middle charge to the left. Since the charges and distances are equal, these repulsive forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, resulting in a net force of zero on the middle charge.

questions.question: A $60\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $240\text{ V}$ power source. Find the current flowing through it.
questions.explanation: Ohm's Law gives the current as $I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{240\text{ V}}{60\,\Omega} = 4\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $12\,\Omega$ resistor has a current of $5\text{ A}$ flowing through it. What is the power dissipated by the resistor?
questions.explanation: Electrical power can be calculated using $P = I^2R = (5\text{ A})^2 \times 12\,\Omega = 25 \times 12 = 300\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A $50\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $100\text{ V}$ power supply. Find the power dissipated by the resistor.
questions.explanation: Using the formula $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$, we get $P = \frac{(100\text{ V})^2}{50\,\Omega} = \frac{10{,}000}{50} = 200\text{ W}$.

questions.question: If a charge of $3{,}000\text{ C}$ flows through a conductor in a time of $10$ minutes, what is the current?
questions.explanation: First convert time to seconds: $10$ minutes $= 600\text{ s}$. Electric current is $I = \frac{Q}{t} = \frac{3{,}000\text{ C}}{600\text{ s}} = 5\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A wire has a diameter of $0.00085\text{ m}$. Express this diameter in millimeters (mm).
